docs.lead_paragraph: Emily Whaley, a South Carolina woman with a green thumb and such an eye for color that she helped show flowering Charleston there was bloom beyond azaleas and camellias and turned her backyard into one of the nation's most acclaimed private gardens, died on Monday at her summer home in Flat Rock, N.C. She was 87 and had become something of celebrity since the publication of a memoir, ''Mrs. Whaley and her Charleston Garden,'' last year. Her family said the cause was a stroke.

headline.main: Emily Whaley, Charleston Gardener and Writer, Dies at 87

docs.abstract: Emily Whaley, acclaimed South Carolina gardener and writer, dies at age 87; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Emily Whaley, a South Carolina woman with a green thumb and such an eye for color that she helped show flowering Charleston there was bloom beyond azaleas and camellias and turned her backyard into one of the nation's most acclaimed private gardens,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like a first kiss, getting the car keys for the first time or walking into a bar and buying a first drink, gambling has become a rite of passage for young people on their way to adulthood. With casinos in 26 states and lotteries in 38, youths who have watched their parents choose from a hefty menu of legal gambling activities right in their backyards are going on dates, spending their prom nights and joining college classmates at the nearest casinos.

headline.main: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling

docs.abstract: Gambling is becoming rite of passage for young people on way to adulthood; youths who have watched parents gamble are going on dates, spending prom nights and joining college classmates at nearest casinos; experts on compulsive gambling are concerned about trend; local governments that sponsor lotteries, as well as casino industry and other businesses, enhance appeal of gambling to children by using lottery scratch cards with bright cartoonish graphics, video poker machines resembling video machines and video arcades for children at some casinos that include slot machines that offer prizes instead of money; casino industry is surrounding itself with amusement parks and attractions that appeal to young and give parents reason to bring children along when they visit places like Atlantic City and Las Vegas; charts; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Of more concern than criminal actions and postnatal civil actions that pose legal problems in treating a viable fetus as a ''child'' entitled to state protection is the ineffectiveness of measures aimed at deterring substance abuse during pregnancy (column, June 11). By the time the state intervenes, the fetus has already been exposed to dangerous amounts of toxins.
docs.abstract: Jill Thomsen letter on Bob Herbert's June 11 column cites prenatal civil commitment of drug abusing pregnant women in public treatment centers as way to protect fetus

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert (''Pregnancy and Addiction,'' column, June 11) laments that at one time in Charleston, S.C., ''30 women were arrested 'out of their hospital beds' at the Medical University of South Carolina,'' but he doesn't mention that nurses at the university used to plead with pregnant addicts to enter drug treatment. In 1989 not one of the women kept her appointment at the substance abuse clinic, and each tested positive for cocaine upon returning to the hospital in labor. After delivery each woman again refused treatment.
docs.abstract: Dr Sally L Satel letter on Bob Herbert's June 11 column holds coercive efforts succeed where voluntary programs fail in getting South Carolina drug addicts to curb drug usage during pregnancy

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert (column, June 11) raises critical issues about state intervention in preventing fetal damage caused by drug abuse. It is paradoxical that South Carolina, a major tobacco-producing state, has chosen to prosecute women for child abuse in these situations.
docs.abstract: Prof Theodore Slotkin letter on Bob Herbert's June 11 column holds maternal tobacco smoking is more damaging to fetus than using cocaine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert's June 11 column explains the South Carolina court's decision to incarcerate women who use drugs while pregnant in terms of a judicial wish to deter this behavior. But courts should realize that women addicted to alcohol or other drugs will not say, ''Gee, I'd better not use drugs for nine months because I'll be sent to jail!'' This type of thinking doesn't happen to addicts of either sex.
docs.abstract: Letter from Nancy Brach, halfway house worker, on Bob Herbert's June 11 column holds treating pregnant drug abusers is far cheaper than imprisoning them

docs.lead_paragraph: A jury has awarded $43.9 million to a 10-year-old Brooklyn boy whose brain was damaged at birth, a condition his lawyers argued was made worse by the mistakes of a hospital staff. The verdict late Friday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn capped a two-week trial before Justice Melvin Barasch. Thomas A. Moore, lawyer for the boy, Naquan Santiago, argued that Naquan was injured when he was deprived of oxygen by the staff at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn on Aug. 11, 1987.

headline.main: A Brain-Damaged Boy Is Awarded $44 Million

docs.abstract: Jury awards $43.9 million to Naquan Santiago, 10-year-old Brooklyn boy whose brain was damaged at birth, condition his lawyers argued was made worse by mistakes of staff at Kings County Hospital (S)
